title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with technical, media, communications, or marketing background will be assigned to the office. Additionally, individuals will be appointed within various components and offices of the Department to support the efforts. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary responsible for coordinating activities to counter violent extremism across all department components. This includes identifying risk factors and populations targeted by extremist propaganda. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is tasked with identifying risk factors contributing to violent extremism, populations targeted by extremist propaganda, managing outreach activities, ensuring research informs counter-extremism efforts, and developing a department-wide strategy for countering violent extremism. The Department of Homeland Security's Office for Countering Violent Extremism is responsible for developing and maintaining a department-wide strategy to counter violent extremism. This strategy includes addressing the Department's counter-messaging program, engagement and outreach activities related to countering violent extremism, and the use of cooperative agreements with various partners. The Department of Homeland Security's Office for Countering Violent Extremism oversees activities related to countering violent extremism, including engagement, outreach, cooperative agreements, and program evaluation. They also focus on respecting privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties, and identifying research requirements. The Department of Homeland Security's Office for Countering Violent Extremism evaluates programs using outcome-based metrics, recommends research requirements, assesses extremist propaganda methods, and establishes a counter-messaging program. The Department of Homeland Security's Office for Countering Violent Extremism is tasked with coordinating activities to counter extremist propaganda, crafting strategic counter-messages, representing the department in coordinating with other federal agencies and NGOs, and collaborating with the Department of State on international extremism issues. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates with the Department of State on international extremism issues, provides guidance on grant usage, and administers grant programs in collaboration with the Federal Emergency Management Agency. A memorandum of understanding is established outlining roles for grant administration. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, establishes a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, along with other agencies, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program targeting violent extremism, including eligibility criteria and monitoring of grant applications. A prohibition exists for groups funding violent extremist activities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress for the next five fiscal years detailing the Department's programs and policies, budget, and staffing dedicated to countering violent extremism. A prohibition exists for community groups or organizations funding violent extremist activities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress detailing the Department's programs, budget, staffing, activities, outcome-based metrics, outreach organizations, and grants related to countering violent extremism. The annual report to Congress by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism includes details on outreach organizations, grants awarded, personnel and funding levels, adaptation to threat environment, protection of civil rights and liberties, evaluation of grant program effectiveness, and incorporation of lessons learned. The annual report to Congress by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism includes evaluation of grant program effectiveness, incorporation of lessons learned from other departments and agencies, definition of violent extremism as ideologically motivated terrorist activities, authorization of funding for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism, and termination of the section after five years. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism will receive funding for fiscal years 2016 through 2020, with $6,000,000 allocated for the grant program. This section will terminate five years after enactment.
